div.l: They tolden eueri man that he was wood
He was agast so of Noes flood
Throuȝ fantasie that of his vanite
He had bouȝt him kneding tubbes iij
And had hem hanged in the roof aboue
And that he praid hem for goddes loue
To sitten in the roof par company
The folk gan laughen at his fantasie
In to the roof they kekyn and they gape
And torned al his harme vnto a iape
For what so that this Carpenter ansuerde
It was for nouȝt noman his reson herde
With othes grete he was so sworn a doun
That he was holden wood in al the toun
For eueri clerk anon helde with othir
He seid the man was wood my leue brothir
And eueri wiȝt gan laughen at this strif
Thus swifed was the Carpenters wif
For all his keping and his ielousie
And Absolon hath kist hir neither yhe
And Nicholas is scalded in the toute
This tale is doon and god saue al the route
Here beginneth the Prolog of the Reue

Whan folk han laughen
at this nice cas ·
Of Absolon and hende Nicholas
Diuers folk diuersly they seide
But for the more part thei loude and pleide
Ne at this tale I saugh noman him greue
But it were onli Oswolde the Reue
Be cause he was of Carpenters craft
A litil Ire is in his hert Ilaft
He gan to grucche ⁊and blamed it a lite
